This game is the very embodiment of what one might call an â€œeight-out-of-tenâ€ title. Nowadays, we are inundated with blogs, websites, magazines, and YouTube videos that dispense extravagant scores, yet everyone seems to have forgotten what truly defines a masterpiece and what, conversely, constitutes a mediocre work. This game stands precisely in the middle ground.

It teeters on the edge of brilliance, a single step away from greatness, yet it lacks perhaps the most vital quality of any true work of art: its uniqueness. Though this game boasts the most exquisite art style I have ever witnessed in my lifeâ€”a breathtaking vision of a fantastical city steeped in politics, racial diversity, and towering walls reminiscent of Attack on Titanâ€”its identity feels derivative. Its fairy-tale aesthetic evokes the finest of Disneyâ€™s magic, the princeâ€™s enchanted thorns recall Sleeping Beauty, and its dreamlike cinematic interludes conjure the sketches of Leonardo da Vinci himself. Thereâ€™s even a subtle nod to one of my all-time favorite video games: when characters unleash their abilities, their bodies transform into red-lined figures that unmistakably echo the protagonist of Breath of Fire: Dragon Quarter. Even the menu animations are crafted with an almost sublime elegance.

The issue lies in its narrative. For all its visual splendor, the story lacks distinction. You continue playing not out of narrative investment, but simply because the game is beautiful and its gameplay loop deeply satisfying. It borrows the most appealing aspects of Persona 5 and reimagines them through a fantasy lens. The cherry on top is a stroke of genius: the ability to slay low-level enemies instantly and still gain experience pointsâ€”a true blessing from the heavens.

SPOILER: Having completed the game, my opinion remains unchanged from the first few hours. The plot is archetypalâ€”a king, a prince, a curse, the inevitable power struggle, and a relentless antagonist whose obsession leads to monstrous transformation. Louis is arguably the highlight of the story, bearing a striking resemblance to N from PokÃ©mon Black and White. In borrowing Persona 5â€™s finest mechanics, the developers also appropriated its most memorable boss fights, culminating in a finale that mirrors that of its inspirationâ€”sans the true ending.

As I said from the outset, this is a phenomenal, immensely enjoyable video gameâ€”yet, as a work of art, it is ultimately mediocre.

8/10. It could have been so much more with just a few refinements in its writing. But if we are to judge purely by its art design, then it belongs to an entirely different realm.

Overall, I recommend Metaphor: ReFantazio if you enjoy JRPGs.

If youâ€™ve played Persona 3, 4, or 5, the gameplay loop will feel instantly familiar. It features turn-based combat, a day-by-day calendar system, and a bond (social link/confidant) mechanic, along with its own take on the concept through Archetypes, which function as spiritual cousins to Personas. As in the Persona series, much of Metaphorâ€™s core draws from Jungian psychology and social themes. That makes sense since many of the same developers who worked on the modern Persona games were involved in creating this one.

As youâ€™d expect from ATLUS, the presentation, voice acting, cutscenes, and music are all top-notch, and the game feels polished throughout.

That said, Metaphor also carries over a few of the notable things from Persona that some people will like and others may not. The game is long, and the story pacing can feel uneven in places. It also throws a lot of systems and mechanics at you early on, which can be a bit overwhelming at times. Fortunately, itâ€™s forgiving when it comes to time management and figuring things out. As long as you stay on top of doing things, you can experience most of what the game offers. By the end of the game, I had every quest complete, every bond maxed, and still had extra days in-game to spare for grinding levels and Archetypes or whatever I wanted before the finale.

While Metaphorâ€™s characters and story didnâ€™t hit me quite as hard emotionally as the Persona games did, I do think they're pretty good, and I think comparing to Persona is a high bar to clear. Its world is imaginative, the mechanics are satisfying, and itâ€™s definitely worth playing or at least trying the demo if you enjoy story-driven RPGs with depth and style.

Metaphor ReFantazio is the latest Atlus game. In short it is similar to the Persona games, but then in a fantasy world.

As you would expect the graphics are very striking, with creatively designed and intuitive menus and UI.  The soundtrack is very memorable with the monk chants, backed by the classical orchestra. Also the performance is great, it runs without any issues on my pc on the highest graphical settings. 

The combat is as usual very addictive. The monster design is pretty cool as well, there are a lot of monsters that are definitely inspired from the Jheronimus Bosch paintings. You start out in dungeons in real time action combat, where you can eventually enter turn based combat. The press turn system from the Shin Megami Tensei games is back, where you gain extra turns when hitting weaknesses or crits. It makes the combat feel tactical. 

The thing that didn't return are the demons. Those are now replaced by Archetypes, classes that each have their own playstyle with strengths and weaknesses. The fun part is, that you can level those and evolve on every character in your party. And by time and experience, you can inherit skills from those Archetypes, which you can mix & match in the current Archetype you are using.

The story is compelling and it uses a lot of fantasy tropes. Sometimes it reminded me a bit of Studio Ghibli movies or the Final Fantasy games in a way. I loved traveling the world and learning all the different tribes and their cultures on the journey. There are plenty of interesting characters where you can build bonds with, each with their own story.  The characters each have a memorable design and they look so stylish. Some stories were very touching or surprising.

The main story starts of strong and intriguing. and it really feels like a journey you make together with your party, while you uncover several mysteries and defeat mighty foes in their dungeons. Somewhere around the end of the game, the pacing slows down, and feels a bit like a slog. For me, it felt like there were too many twists and fakeout endings thrown at you. That mixed with a lot of repetition in long dialogues and cutscenes, made me feel a bit fatigued. It makes me wish they extended the middle part of the story a bit more.

Of course you can grind for passive skills and do sidequests as well, which is very similar to the Persona gameplay loop. It's all calendar based, but you have plenty of time to do what you want to do.

Overall, I think it is another great Atlus game, but I wish the ending wasn't such a slog. They were able to improve the fun combat from Persona even more, and their way of writing a fantasy story feels refreshing.

This game is more than just "medieval fantasy Persona." It is certainly the same dna, but it does plenty different, most of which I think is done better.

Pros:
- Strategic combat with an in-depth "class" system akin to Final Fantasy Tactics, where you unlock Archetypes, level them up, then can carry over a number of their skills to another Archetype.
- A MUCH better paced story then Persona series. The time between story beats, dungeon lengths, and dialogue in general, flow a lot better and keeps you hooked. 
- The Calendar being used to give the game actual travel time between destinations is wonderful to see and makes the adventure truly feel grand.
- I found all the NPCs in your party, and that you gain relationship levels with, to be fantastic. 
- The benefits gained from raising your "Confidant" levels are more useful then in Persona, even if not as varied.
- The Turn Icon combat is brought over from SMTV, which I think is one of the best turn based combat systems, rewarding buffs, debuffs, and weakness exploits much more then the average JRPG
- The main dungeon crawls are a truly fun, multi-calendar day experience, with the length really adding to the pre-dungeon planning and in dungeon strategy. I actually enjoyed the fact I ran out of MP and had to find a checkpoint room to retreat from and return the next day. 
- The music is fantastic
- The game does an amazing job of making the most out of its budget, using really creative ricks to emulate the feeling a truly grand, continent-spanning journey. 

Cons:
- The side dungeons are your standard repetitious Persona fare. Though, I will give them credit for being finite, none-randomized places you can fully explore.
- The late game grind for the MAG and XP you need to unlock all the Archetypes and inheritable skills you want can be a bit of a drag.
- A mid game unlock takes away some of the magic and majesty of travel
- The auto-play dialogue option often cuts off the last couple words of the voice acting

Neutral:
- Not being able to romance a companion is a bummer, but it makes sense in the context of the story 
- While the music is fantastic, the tracks are pretty limited
- Overall graphics and animation are good enough for the budget, with the art direction, character, and enemy designs doing a lot of heavy lifting. 

Overall Rating: Best in Class (JRPG)

Metaphor: ReFantazio is a game I believe everyone should have the chance to experience.

The combat takes the straightforward system from Persona and SMT and refines it to near perfection. While I'm sure some improvements could be made here or there, I can confidently say that this game has the best JRPG turn-based combat to date. 

While the story takes a break during the last fifth of the game to allow the player to complete all side content, I found it to be tightly written and engaging the whole way through - something that's rather uncommon for most JRPGs. Many of the characters are amazingly written as well, and while some of them can be rather simple, the main cast of this game is top tier to me.
(The only caveat I'll give for the story is that the long break towards the end made me lose interest for a while - I originally started playing the game on release, but was put off by this gap and moved onto other games, and didn't come back to finish Metaphor until a year later.)

I'm not really a fan of the $70 price being standard for AAA games nowadays, but I think that Metaphor really deserves it. Its consistent quality and quantity stand above nearly every other game with the same price tag. The developers and studio deserve it for the amazing work they've created.

In my view, this is largely superior to the Persona games, with vast gameplay improvements and a story that has parallels to other media in the fantasy genre, but still succeeds. Persona games are great, but are quite similar to one another. Student in Japan that has special powers and discovers other students with the same powers. Metaphor is more like Game of Thrones, where it's a race/competition for the throne after the King's assassination. 

Gameplay is almost 1 to 1 with Persona, but where it differs are the archetypes and the way turns go. Each side has 4 actions that can be extended by getting a crit or hitting a weakness, similar to one more from Persona. The difference is that instead of the same character repeating the action, it goes to the next character while returning you half an action (being unable to pass your turn with that action point). Archetypes are classes with a base skillset and affinities. While most higher tier archetypes are better, "weaker" ones might have skills that the stronger ones don't have. These skills can be inherited by other archetypes, provided that the character has leveled up the other archetype. This is one of the best parts of the game; mixing and matching skills to strengthen your equipped archetypes. Leveling them up can either be done by equipping them before battles, or using certain items that you can find or get via leveling up an archetype that has gotten to level 20. Each time they level up beyond that point, you get one of those items. Maxing archetypes also gives the character that got it to level 20 a stat boost in a certain area. 

The story is akin to Game of Thrones, with you and others vying for the throne. It's effectively an election, with you and other candidates traveling around the continent. The story tackles issues like the poor vs the wealthy, and different races butting heads. When games typically tackle race, it ends up being cringy or a one sided agenda fest. This game manages to make it a big point, while not putting it above everything else by a mile. The main focus is on stopping the main antagonist, while dealing with others that are after the throne. Can't say much else cuz spoilers.

The music is great. Not much else to say, other than there could be more individual tracks.

The graphics are a mixed bag. Some things in the game look great, while other things look like a cartoony PS3 game. The main highlight are the models of enemies and archetypes. The lowlights are many of the NPC models, mainly up close. They look like they just stepped out of a Warriors engine game, with low detail faces and clothing. Environmental textures go back and forth between good looking and dated.

The art style is beautifully simple. Much of the game has the same color, and environments don't change too much. However, what's there looks really good. A subtle, satisfying art style that doesn't overstep nor underwhelm. When it gets wilder, it's when there's a boss fight or a corrupted area. 

This is for you if you enjoy Persona. The story and setting are a lot different, but the gameplay beats are the same, with the calendar and battle systems making a great return. The current sale is another excuse to get it. Try out the demo. I've played the full game twice and I think I'll play it again.

I initially gave this a negative. It's more of a neutral. I'll attempt to explain.  

I was mostly having fun for most of the runtime.  Combat is engaging.  If you're high enough level over your opponent you dont even enter turn based combat so it saves time. Dungeon crawling is hardcore. Meaning that your mana is finite. It doesn't regen unless you play as a mage and farm mobs for awhile to regen the groups mana pool or use very limited items.  All of these things I enjoyed....and then there was the softlock episodes.  

A few encounters in this game, namely bosses, you have to have a very specific setup to defeat them or you lose, even on the easiest difficulty. This is due to several bosses just being gimmick fights where you need a specific spell to either debuff them or decurse yourself.  Well if you dont have these spells and you can't go back to level up somemore, you're kinda fucked.  You better have an alternate save file or you're cooked.  

This is why I originally gave this a neg review.  I was pissed.  Luckily I didn't lose too much time but a new player would be very confused by some of the boss encounters here and likely be stuck too.  Ultimately I beat this game and had a good time, even playing new game plus now on Regicide difficulty, which is technically insane difficulty, but with you carrying over your items from the prevoious playthrough, quickly becomes trivial.  The equipment carries you in the early new game plus.  

Like I said, combat is flashy.  You can bash the opponent a few times, dodge their attack, bash them again and then they're stunned.  You can then get an advantage.  Atlus does this in nearly every one of their games. The AI auto battler in Metaphor is truly unique.  I used it many times.  Some of the harder bosses I had to take over but for the most part, the AI will use the most effecient spells to dispatch the enemy. Normally this means overspending mana.  But for about 75% of the game I used the auto battler.  It's just so good.  The AI already knows the weaknesses of your enemy before you do and will sometimes just auto attack to finish the opponent off, because the AI already calculated its health and used a more mana efficient method to kill them. Truly impressive.

The story sucks.  Characters suck.  Bland, cliche, wooden characters. The main protag is a bag of white rice.   I skipped so many cutscenes and dialogue scenes.  I just didn't care after awhile.  Shame too bc the voice acting is very good.  Music is very impressive as well.  

At some point in the game you're on a walker type thing.  This reminded me of playing another game called Last Oasis here on steam.  A survival where you build walker vehicles to traverse large distances.  You can leave your walker while traveling to a mission and just look outside.  It immediately reminded me of Last oasis and walking around in the walker I build myself.  

The pixie voice actor needs to shut the fuck up btw.  ANyone that has played this game knows what I'm talking about.  She will incessently bark in your ear every time someone gets a debuff, misses, gets a crit, is near death, etc.  Very annoying.  

That's about it.  It's a quality game.

Atlus delivers once again! This game is a fast paced JRPG. Like its Persona predecessors this game delivers turn based action with a deadline that you have to meet. Metaphor Re: Fantazio stylishly delivers beautiful visuals with unique gameplay. Archetypes allow you to employ visually pleasing attacks that make you feel like you're in an anime. Thanks to being able to see foes on the battlefield while exploring combat can be punishing if you're caught off guard and ambushed while also allowing you to turn the tide of battle if you ambush the enemies first. Boss fights are challenging and rewarding. The games story is intriguing, beautiful and altogether strange with meticulously animated cutscenes, and excellent voice acting that pull the player in. I would highly recommend this game to newcomers and JRPG veterans alike.

If you like Persona5 you will like this game too, as others have said it follows Atlas' general style with the combination of hanging with your pals and dungeons that are made easier by spending time with allies. As always the music, art, and writing are all phenomenal. The game has what feels like hundreds of themes and messages that tie back to the main story; they make the world feel vast and even real at times. It doesn't ask you to think one way is correct or incorrect, it shows both sides and lets you decide, which seems like its the actual main purpose of this game's creation other than the obvious. Each character felt more likeable and more sincere than they did in P5 which is a massive accomplishment. Each character gets a chance to shine and continues to be used in tandem with eachother to further the story and bonds between them. 

    The combat never got boring for me thanks to the plenty of archetypes and the various party members introduced at an even pace to bring something new, consistently. The greatest thing about it for me was the rewind button, if you don't like the way the battle has been going, just start over and do it a different way. It allows you to gain info on your enemy such as weaknesses or strengths to use after you rewind. Which you think would cheapen the fights and make them less enjoyable, and to a certain extent, it does. However if you have played any Atlas game before you will know that they love to make you suffer with some enemies and boss designs, where it simply would be completely unfair and unfun without a rewind button. If it didn't exist on quite a few fights you would die simply to not knowing the enemy repels wind attacks; which many times you may be able to intuit but for the times where you can't it doesn't feel like your fault as there was no way to know. Lastly screw the boss that instakills your party if you have repel equipment on. Because it doesn't tell you that repel equipment will get you killed! You have to look at the wiki! It's also just a damage test, which is more strategy than raw stats at the point in the game it appears so it isn't dragging it down.

    Lastly the story is simply incredible, it has it's lows but they serve to elevate the highs. I've never been more afraid of a single fictional man then I did when I played this game. On top of my jaw sitting on the floor due to the plethora of reveals which were so cleverly handled. Very few characters in this game are dull, and if they are, they aren't around for more than a few minutes at a time. Every character that appears again and again is always fun to  hear speak. The world building is mostly found in the memorandum but I love it so it's a plus for me. I don't know of any other game that explains it's economy down to the origin of its tender. I am no good critic, in fact I am very dumb but I love this game despite some of its minor flaws that ultimately come down to preference.

The game starts out exploring this concept in interesting ways, and the devs went all-out to pack the first few hours with crazy art, good characters, and amazing boss design. Atlus's PS2-era dungeons are still very much in play here, but as with the Persona games, I could overlook this flaw because the rest of the package was just so damn good.

But it quickly lost steam. After the first portion of the game (which is all part of the demo, roughly 5-8 hours), the theme of "fantasy as a catalyst for a better world" takes a backseat to a far more generic theme of "we're going to change society by doing stuff better." Dozens of hours of the game are spent in pursuit of what feels like a high school class president's campaign: "The way stuff is done now sucks. Vote for me and I'll do stuff better." NPC comes to you complaining of overwhelming prejudice and poverty? Your answer for them never strays far from "Well, then let's change the world." This gets old quickly, especially because it keeps discussion of key themes like racism, prejudice, poverty, militarism, and religious fundamentalism at a very juvenile level.

The combat system is generally very well done and super stylish, and should satisfy fans of Persona 5 Royal or Clair Obscur: Expedition 33. Character moves are varied, the Archetype system gives you lots of party configurations, and enemies are hard enough to provide a challenge without overwhelming you, provided you're doing side content like bounty hunts. The combat system is by far the biggest selling point of this game in my opinion. It kept me going through the more boring parts. Occasionally fights can be unbalanced or hinge too much on luck, but by and large it was great. 

As for characters/party members, this is the least interesting cast of any Atlus game I've played (Persona 3 Reload, Persona 4 Golden, and Persona 5 Royal). The first few characters that join your party quickly become uninteresting or leave. By the 30-hour mark or so, there was only one party member who was still interesting, and that's how it stayed until I finished the game forty hours later. Like many anime-inspired games, Metaphor: ReFantazio plays it safe by picking an anime trope for a character and giving them some quirk that is supposed to make them three-dimensional. Some games succeed at this (see: most Persona games, many Final Fantasy games). Metaphor does not. Good characters always do the right thing. Bad characters always do bad stuff. Characters change their entire worldview at the drop of a hat, again like high school kids.

This makes the moments that are supposed to be "big" feel very small and inconsequential, even eye-rolling. When tragedy struck one of the late-game party members, I did not care at all because the devs did not do the work to make me care. There were moments when I literally rolled my eyes and scoffed at the childish simplicity of the writing. For example, one candidate in the contest to become king/queen is a woman who vows to break up the wealth of the elites and spread it among the people--that is, a socialist. But in one scene, one of her followers announces that he murdered a rich guy and took all of his money. The socialist character said, almost verbatim, "Huh. I never imagined that my followers would take my ideas of destroying the elite class as a call to KILL the elite class." Then and there, she stops running to be queen and endorses your character. I had to put down the game for a few days at this point because I just couldn't take it seriously. Only in badly written anime games do characters put so little thought into their own beliefs that they can be changed so easily.

Examples like this abound. In another scene, your party is exploring the ancient temple of a foreign tribe. A couple of characters comment to a member of the tribe that the murals in the temple do not seem to match up with the teachings of the tribe's religion. And just like that, after some foreigners comment on some art, the tribe abandons key tenets of their religion. This was another moment where I just had to take a few days. I expect more maturity and nuance in writing than this, even in video games.

The story has a few golden moments of heartwarming sincerity, and I appreciated these. Every few hours something happened that reminded me how much I loved the game's beginning. Despite some wasted opportunities and shoddy writing, the story gets a narrow passing grade from me.

A quick note on graphics: like most Atlus games, this game does not have AAA graphics, or anything even close. At first, the incredible art direction helped me overlook this, but eventually the stiff character animations and weirdly shaped heads/eyes began to rub me the wrong way. Essentially the graphics are on a par with Persona 5 Royal. This is not a good thing. A studio as storied and experienced as Atlus should have the resources to put together a better-looking game to tell their story. There's no excuse for this, particularly because Persona 5 Reload and Shin Megami V: Vengeance both looked so much more modern. 

All in all, I give this game a 7/10. If you have 80 hours to kill and feel like a Persona-like experience, this is the game for you. If you want those 80 hours to feel very well-spent, there are better options, especially if you like your games to have strong stories. Persona 3-5 and Shin Megami Tensei V: Vengeance each offer similarly excellent combat systems and do more to distinguish themselves. For someone trying to break into JRPG's, I would recommend one of those instead.

It is also visible that the creators had an idea for a graphic setting and world design as such that distinguishes itself from the rest of the titles on the market.
The gameplay loop isn't necessarily "bad," but it is the main source of my disappointment. Essentially, this is just Persona wrapped in a High Fantasy setting. The calendar system, the time management, the confidant mechanics, and even the combat and exploration mirror its sister series almost exactly. While we use archetypes (classes) instead of Personas, this feels like a purely cosmetic change. I love Persona, but I expected more innovation and variety from a new IP - especially knowing they are capable of unique titles like Catherine.
Regrettably, the story and characters failed to grab me. The intro was gripping, mostly due to the mystery of a new world, but the narrative quickly became tedious. The NPCs feel one dimensional, the plot is predictable, and the main antagonist is a generic "evil for the sake of being evil" villain. Looking back, only one character from the entire cast actually left a lasting impression on me.
On the technical side, the game runs well. Playing a year after launch, I didn't encounter any bugs or issues. I played partially on Steam Deck, and aside from a few minor FPS drops, the experience was smooth. However, the lack of Ultrawide monitor support is a huge negative. As a long time Atlus fan, this is the only game where I had stopped playing right at the start of the final dungeon, uninstalled the game, and was glad to never bother with it again. it's not a bad game by any means, but I find it baffling that it gets such an overwhelmingly positive reception, despite having plenty of flaws both in story and gameplay.

The main reason that I'm so disappointed by it, is because that this is a new IP, which meant that they could go wild and do whatever they wanted, crafted a well written and in depth story, explore new gameplay ideas, innovate on their formulas, but instead what we got is basically "Persona 5, medieval edition" with incredibly poor writing and stagnant gameplay. 

Generally speaking, Atlus games never did have the best writing in them, but they did tackle their themes and plots in a decent way that it didn't constantly bother me, so I could give them a pass and enjoy the gameplay and character moments in them, however, in M:R, the worldbuilding and plot are so poorly written that I couldn't take the story seriously at all at any point. The main theme the game tackles is Racism, a heavy, complex, and important theme, however, the way you are shown how racism is portrayed in this world is just throwing shallow stereotypes at you about the various races in the game, and that's it. And hilariously enough, in many cases, the stereotypes turn out to be completely correct, further undermining the point of the main theme. In many points in the plot, it felt to me that the writers think that race and culture are one and the same, meaning that if you're one race, no matter your upbringing or your personality, your race determines everything, which, again, undermines the main point of the plot.

The writing, beyond the main theme, is again, not very good. Your party members are one dimensional, most of the plot is your basic JRPG plot of "Kill the main villain with the power of friendship and save the day" and some of the "twists" if you can call them that, just made me roll my eyes, because they too, manage to undermine the main theme.
I had hoped that the game would go into depth about it's themes with the main party, with each person conveying a different point of view, having conflicts about different matters ,but most of the party feel really samey. They are all nice, agreeable and get along just fine, which is really nice if it was real life, but in a story that's pretty boring. The last two characters that get added to your party are the exception, but even they aren't particularly outstanding or have too much time to shine, unfortunately.

The gameplay side of things isn't much better, which isn't to say that the gameplay is bad, far from it, it's just that if you played any of the recent Atlus titles, you won't be too amazed by the gameplay, and considering that this is a new IP, one would imagine that they would want to innovate instead of retreading old ground, and unfortunately, they didn't really innovate. The main difference in M:R between other Atlus games is Archtypes.

The Archetype system, which is essentially your "job" system in this game, is pretty okay, nothing too mind blowing. You can freely set your party members to different Archtypes based on the situation and try out different strategies, such as warrior, mage, healer etc, which is pretty nice, however, the amount of menuing you have to do every time you decide to change between Archtypes and their gear is pretty annoying.
An additional annoyance that I found about the system, is that by the endgame, every party member has a a unique Archtype only they can use, and they require two specific Archtypes to be maxed before being unlocked, if you're like me, and you enjoy experimenting, and you might find, like I did, that you weren't close to getting the relevant Archtypes to max, and you'll feel like you were punished for experimenting by the game telling you "oh, you didn't level these specific two archtypes to max for character x? too bad, get to grinding if you want it". In the game's credit, you don't have to unlock them, the game isn't too difficult on its normal difficulty, but it does feel like it arbitrarily punished you for using the system as it was supposedly meant to be used.

Dungeons are pretty lackluster, both main story dungeons, and side dungeons. The main dungeons feel like they're big for no reason and don't really have any interesting gimmicks or mechanics to make the gameplay more varied, for example, in one dungeon you have 30 minutes before you die, in another, you have to hide occasionally from a difficult monster, not very unique or interesting in both ideas or execution.
The side dungeons are pretty bland, they look boring, mostly long brown or grey hallways sometimes broken up with a large empty room or a ladder to a different floor of bland brown or grey hallways and big empty rooms with nothing in them except enemies, sometimes it's caves, sometimes it's ruins, sometimes it's a big empty, flat forest. I have no idea if the side dungeons were randomly generated during development, but I won't be surprised if they were.

Many times during the game I had hoped that I will encounter unique situations that require you to really experiment with the Archtype system and really challange you in more than a "big damage number" or "HP bloat" type of way, but unfortunately, that isn't the case. Mobs are usually dealt the same way they are dealt in the persona games, which is to say, abuse elemental weakness, kill enemy, move on. Boss fights weren't particularly memorable to me, so I can't recall any interesting gimmicks if there were any at all, take it as you will.
I will say that there was one dungeon in the beginning of the game that if your party had a certain Archtype present during combat the common enemy type in the dungeon would enrage and could cause a wipe to your party, which meant that you had to change your Archtypes to deal with the situation, but that's literally the only dungeon I remember that happening, which is unfortunate,  because that kind of mechanic could be really interesting to explore and could provide much gameplay vareity and depth in my opinion.

In short, if I had to give the game a score, I'd give it a 5, it's not bad, it's not the worst game ever made, it's okay. If you're really interested in the game, or just want another JRPG to play and you think it needs to be this one, I would suggest to wait until a deep sale.

Itâ€™s difficult to give this game a clear-cut rating, particularly when viewing it through the lens of the Persona series. However, judging it as a new IP from Atlus, my score unfortunately reflects my overall disappointment.
Starting from the undoubted positives: the audiovisual presentation. The Atlus Sound Team delivered yet again, creating a soundtrack that stays with you long after you finish playing. It is also visible that the creators had an idea for a graphic setting and world design as such that distinguishes itself from the rest of the titles on the market.
The gameplay loop isn't necessarily "bad," but it is the main source of my disappointment. Essentially, this is just Persona wrapped in a High Fantasy setting. The calendar system, the time management, the confidant mechanics, and even the combat and exploration mirror its sister series almost exactly. While we use archetypes (classes) instead of Personas, this feels like a purely cosmetic change. I love Persona, but I expected more innovation and variety from a new IP - especially knowing they are capable of unique titles like Catherine.
Regrettably, the story and characters failed to grab me. The intro was gripping, mostly due to the mystery of a new world, but the narrative quickly became tedious. The NPCs feel one dimensional, the plot is predictable, and the main antagonist is a generic "evil for the sake of being evil" villain. Looking back, only one character from the entire cast actually left a lasting impression on me.
On the technical side, the game runs well. Playing a year after launch, I didn't encounter any bugs or issues. I played partially on Steam Deck, and aside from a few minor FPS drops, the experience was smooth. However, the lack of Ultrawide monitor support is a huge negative. I had to rely on unofficial fixes to get it working. This is especially frustrating considering that Persona 5: The Phantom X supports ultrawide natively. How does a gacha spinoff have this feature, but a major new IP doesn't?

As a long time Atlus fan, this is the only game where I had stopped playing right at the start of the final dungeon, uninstalled the game, and was glad to never bother with it again. it's not a bad game by any means, but I find it baffling that it gets such an overwhelmingly positive reception, despite having plenty of flaws both in story and gameplay.

The main reason that I'm so disappointed by it, is because that this is a new IP, which meant that they could go wild and do whatever they wanted, crafted a well written and in depth story, explore new gameplay ideas, innovate on their formulas, but instead what we got is basically "Persona 5, medieval edition" with incredibly poor writing and stagnant gameplay. 

Generally speaking, Atlus games never did have the best writing in them, but they did tackle their themes and plots in a decent way that it didn't constantly bother me, so I could give them a pass and enjoy the gameplay and character moments in them, however, in M:R, the worldbuilding and plot are so poorly written that I couldn't take the story seriously at all at any point. The main theme the game tackles is Racism, a heavy, complex, and important theme, however, the way you are shown how racism is portrayed in this world is just throwing shallow stereotypes at you about the various races in the game, and that's it. And hilariously enough, in many cases, the stereotypes turn out to be completely correct, further undermining the point of the main theme. In many points in the plot, it felt to me that the writers think that race and culture are one and the same, meaning that if you're one race, no matter your upbringing or your personality, your race determines everything, which, again, undermines the main point of the plot.

The writing, beyond the main theme, is again, not very good. Your party members are one dimensional, most of the plot is your basic JRPG plot of "Kill the main villain with the power of friendship and save the day" and some of the "twists" if you can call them that, just made me roll my eyes, because they too, manage to undermine the main theme.
I had hoped that the game would go into depth about it's themes with the main party, with each person conveying a different point of view, having conflicts about different matters ,but most of the party feel really samey. They are all nice, agreeable and get along just fine, which is really nice if it was real life, but in a story that's pretty boring. The last two characters that get added to your party are the exception, but even they aren't particularly outstanding or have too much time to shine, unfortunately.

The gameplay side of things isn't much better, which isn't to say that the gameplay is bad, far from it, it's just that if you played any of the recent Atlus titles, you won't be too amazed by the gameplay, and considering that this is a new IP, one would imagine that they would want to innovate instead of retreading old ground, and unfortunately, they didn't really innovate. The main difference in M:R between other Atlus games is Archtypes.

The Archetype system, which is essentially your "job" system in this game, is pretty okay, nothing too mind blowing. You can freely set your party members to different Archtypes based on the situation and try out different strategies, such as warrior, mage, healer etc, which is pretty nice, however, the amount of menuing you have to do every time you decide to change between Archtypes and their gear is pretty annoying.
An additional annoyance that I found about the system, is that by the endgame, every party member has a a unique Archtype only they can use, and they require two specific Archtypes to be maxed before being unlocked, if you're like me, and you enjoy experimenting, and you might find, like I did, that you weren't close to getting the relevant Archtypes to max, and you'll feel like you were punished for experimenting by the game telling you "oh, you didn't level these specific two archtypes to max for character x? too bad, get to grinding if you want it". In the game's credit, you don't have to unlock them, the game isn't too difficult on its normal difficulty, but it does feel like it arbitrarily punished you for using the system as it was supposedly meant to be used.

Dungeons are pretty lackluster, both main story dungeons, and side dungeons. The main dungeons feel like they're big for no reason and don't really have any interesting gimmicks or mechanics to make the gameplay more varied, for example, in one dungeon you have 30 minutes before you die, in another, you have to hide occasionally from a difficult monster, not very unique or interesting in both ideas or execution.
The side dungeons are pretty bland, they look boring, mostly long brown or grey hallways sometimes broken up with a large empty room or a ladder to a different floor of bland brown or grey hallways and big empty rooms with nothing in them except enemies, sometimes it's caves, sometimes it's ruins, sometimes it's a big empty, flat forest. I have no idea if the side dungeons were randomly generated during development, but I won't be surprised if they were.

Many times during the game I had hoped that I will encounter unique situations that require you to really experiment with the Archtype system and really challange you in more than a "big damage number" or "HP bloat" type of way, but unfortunately, that isn't the case. Mobs are usually dealt the same way they are dealt in the persona games, which is to say, abuse elemental weakness, kill enemy, move on. Boss fights weren't particularly memorable to me, so I can't recall any interesting gimmicks if there were any at all, take it as you will.
I will say that there was one dungeon in the beginning of the game that if your party had a certain Archtype present during combat the common enemy type in the dungeon would enrage and could cause a wipe to your party, which meant that you had to change your Archtypes to deal with the situation, but that's literally the only dungeon I remember that happening, which is unfortunate,  because that kind of mechanic could be really interesting to explore and could provide much gameplay vareity and depth in my opinion.

In short, if I had to give the game a score, I'd give it a 5, it's not bad, it's not the worst game ever made, it's okay. If you're really interested in the game, or just want another JRPG to play and you think it needs to be this one, I would suggest to wait until a deep sale.

This is from the perspective of someone who has put hundreds of hours in both the mainline Megami Tensei series and the Persona series. 

First, the good. Incredible soundtrack, colors and presentation, character designs, atmosphere, story premise, it all seems like a complete package. A medieval fantasy Game of Thrones-esqe tug and pull of political power to overthrow a tyrannical General who commits Regicide. and that's just in the first few hours. Such a powerful start.

However, thats when it all falls apart too. The combat in this game is beyond unforgiving and oppressive. I had an easier time with Shin Megami Tensei on the SNES, and that should tell you how bad it is. I don't know if this game is geared toward the small percentage of Persona fans who are obsessed with perfecting their playthroughs by beating every dungeon in 1 day with perfect mana management, but it certainly feels like it. The first dungeon in the game is an 8 floor tower. Yes, you are given 2 weeks to do it, and the game warns you to not put in off in lieu of sidequests and other content, but it still feels like its not enough. I spent at least 5 days getting thru the whole tower, a few more grinding levels to beat the boss, and it still was not enough. he spawns nonstop zombie adds and powers them up while spamming mundoon, a medium level spell at you. All this for the FIRST DUNGEON BOSS. Absolutely insane. the ramp up in this game is oppressive and the mana management requires an excel spreadsheet if you dont want to run out of mana in 3 encounters. I am playing on normal difficulty for reference. I cannot beat the first boss and dont have time to experience any other content within the time constraint either. I cant reccomend a game that won't even let me play it unless I make perfect combat decisions every turn. no room for error whatsoever. Not to mention the game is designed to not allow you to grind forever, you have limited mana and mana restorative consumables, and you have to advance a day to get more. you only get so many days and in every other one of these games it felt like enough. not in this one.
